column1: API promotes parenting practices that create strong
column2: healthy emotional bonds between children and their parents. For life. So they can take those bonds with them into their adult lives and share them with their children. And their children can do the same. A life cycle of compassion and connection.

Parenting As A Hero's Journey - featuring API's Lysa Parker and Barbara Nicholson
Do you think of yourself as an ostracized weirdo or a hero on a journey? The Old Story
column2: with its demands for cultural conformity
column3: wants you to believe you are crazy for questioning it
column4: much less taking steps away from its prescription for living your life and enculturating your children. The New Story
column6: views your impulse to question and abandon culture
column9: the first step on an epic Hero's Journey.

column2: you're still a freak for questioning and abandoning culture
column3: much less trying to change the world
column4: but Evolution Could Not Happen Without The Freaks-of-Nature Leading The Way.

column1: So hoist your freak flag and meet us over at the  Parenting As A Hero's Journey website  where we are headed for a full year of LIVE Virtual Retreats with like-hearted adventurers
column2: freaks and heroes to explore and take home with us the treasures of conscious living and parenting. As Joseph Campbell
column3: author of The Hero of a Thousand Faces and creator of The Hero's Journey monomyth wheel said
column4: “We must be willing to let go of the life we planned so as to have the life that is waiting for us.”

column1: API's own Lysa Parker and Barbara Nicholson are guides on the journey
column2: discussing  Mindful Parenting: The Spiritual Essence of Attachment.

column1: In the book  Love and Anger
column2: we’ve discussed so far how anger is a natural emotion. A lot of the readers in the book club felt reassured that they weren’t the only ones to have felt this way before. They enjoyed the stories that the shared in chapter 1 to show examples of situations in which we as parents can become angry.

The American Liver Society is founded in memory of everyone that was infected with  Hepatitis C   and other blood borne diseases as a result of tainted blood and blood products. Our mission is to help those Americans that contracted Hepatitis C from the nations blood supply and those affected as a result of the domino affect. Other countries around the world have compensated there victims and are prosecuting some of the people responsible for manufacturing and administering these tainted blood products.Canada has set up an 800 number for people to call to give any information about the tainted blood scandal in there country we would like the American Government to do the same for what is no doubt one of Americas greatest medical tragedies.As an American who has lost a brother to AIDS and Hepatitis C and is also infected with Hepatitis C as a result of tainted blood it is my goal to make sure these companies and people responsible are prosecuted and convicted for there crimes against humanity.This site contains  adult  material and is not suitable for children for we cover topics ranging for murder to sex.

column1: Our staff is committed to making your experience far exceed your expectations!
Endodontics is the science of treating problems with the tissue inside the tooth (dental pulp).
We use the latest technology to ensure a comfortable and thorough diagnosis.
We have two locations serving Nashville and its surrounding areas. Our offices are located in Mt. Juliet and Cookeville.
Our office hours are Monday - Thursday 7am to 5pm.
Click the map to view our locations and to get driving directions.
Endodontists  are dentists who specialize in maintaining teeth through endodontic therapy procedures
column2: involving the soft inner tissue of the teeth
column3: called the pulp. All dentists are trained in diagnosis and endodontic therapy
column5: some teeth can be especially difficult to diagnose and treat.  That’s why you may have been referred to an endodontic specialist.

column1: Dr. Davis attended the University of Tennessee College of Dentistry
column2: graduating in 2001. He then spent five years serving as a general dentist in the US Navy. After fulfilling his active duty commitment
column3: Dr. Davis entered the Endodontic Residency Program at VCU in Richmond
column4: Virginia. He received his Endodontic Specialty Certificate in June of 2008. Dr. Davis volunteers one day a month teaching at the University of Tennessee College of Dentistry as well.

column1: Welcome to the website of Dr. Paul J. Somers Jr.
column2: DPM. Dr. Paul Somers Jr. specializes in all aspects of podiatric medicine. Your feet are an essential part of the body and are many times overlooked. When your feet hurt they can impact your overall health and well-being. When symptoms and ailments are left untreated they can lead to more serious complications.   Podiatry is the medical and surgical specialty that concentrates on the care of your feet. As a trained professional and board-certified podiatrist
column5: is devoted to providing patients with real results in alleviating foot problems. These might include bunions
column11: fractures (and other sports-related injuries) which are easily treated by medical
column12: surgical and orthotic therapies. Our office is equipped to perform laser and shockwave treatments as well as minor surgeries. Dr. Somers also provides surgery at many of the local hospitals including Baptist

column1: Dr. Somers has been in private practice for over thirty years. He is recognized as a Fellow of the American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons and is a Diplomate of the American Board of Podiatric Surgery. He has received additional certification in laser surgery and endoscopic surgery of the heel. He was the first podiatrist in the greater Tennessee area to utilize a laser in performing foot surgery and has performed several thousand laser procedures over the past 30 years. These procedures are performed in the office as well as in a hospital setting on an out-patient basis. Dr. Somers has recently been appointed by Tennessee Governor Phil Bredesen to a second consecutive three-year term on the Board of Podiatric Medical Examiners. Dr. Somers is Chief of the Departments of Podiatry at Centennial Surgery Center. He is on staff at Baptist Hospital
column4: Three Rivers Hospital and Nashville Surgery Center. Dr. Somers is a member of the American Podiatric Medical Association
column5: the Tennessee Podiatric Medical Association and a member of the board of the Healing Arts for the state of Tennessee. He is past President of the Nashville Podiatric Medical Association. Board-Certified Foot and Ankle Surgeon Fellow
column6: American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons Diplomate
column7: American Board of Podiatric Surgery Certified Laser Specialist

hang in there just a few seconds… we're worth the wait.
We fundamentally believe that  you are.
challenge what the market research industry tells you is…
Reasonable we can do it  Better
Possible we can do it  Faster
Normal we can do it  Cheaper
we've challenged it. we've changed it.
Getting the answers you need to make business decisions should not be as slow
column3: or expensive as it is now. At Mizzouri
column4: we’re proud members of Generation Flux — and we clearly see a market research industry that’s in desperate need of fresh new thinking. We’ve turned normal on its head. We’ve explored new business models and technologies (not to mention opportunities to disintermediate on your behalf). And we’ve created something truly disruptive in the process.

column1: You  can  have brilliant and actionable research with global scale
column3: and prices far below current market standards.

column1: This is not about sacrificing quality.
Quite the contrary. At Mizzouri we’re smart about how we structure our business
column4: and how we assemble our team.

column1: And it’s nothing short of a wake up-call for the market research industry.
We are a full service global market research firm.
But we're not like anything you've ever seen before.

We launched Mizzouri to enable clients  to commission the research they want – when they want it and the way they want to buy it. We give our clients the right information at the right time so they can make better business decisions
column2: faster. We work with our clients
we’re on a mission to disrupt the research industry.

column1: Because the rules favour the industry
column2: not the client. Because industry values are largely disconnected from clients’ needs. And
column4: because this was an irresistible puzzle that we really wanted to solve.

column2: we've spent plenty of time on the client side - and nothing fuels disruptive innovation quite like frustration.

column1: Frustration is the mother of invention
It was an unseasonably cold spring in London
column2: England — and an unusually mild one in Nashville
column3: Tennessee — when our three founding partners did something radical. They quit their jobs. They left Global COO
column5: and CFO roles with a mission to transform the market research industry because

column1: Over the course of their careers they had all come to the conclusion that market research as it exists today should be staring extinction squarely in the eye. As former clients
column2: they understood acutely how it feels to desperately need timely
column4: and cost effective information to make business decisions. And after many years of asking
column5: “ why can’t we have that? ” they came to a heady realization:  the impossible isn’t impossible after all.

column1: The ability to triangulate is a powerful thing when you’ve got an industry in your crosshairs. And these three like-minded dissidents have enjoyed a 360° view of market research while with firms such as Procter & Gamble
column9: and Reba McEntire’s Starstruck Entertainment. They have always espoused disruption when it benefits the consumer (which in this case is you
column10: the client). And when it comes to research
column11: they firmly believe you can have all three — great
column13: and inexpensive — when the business model is right.

column1: Call them founders of the research logistics fan club.
It’s one thing to ask your day-to-day suppliers to change. To demand that an entire industry change is another thing altogether. It takes bravery for clients to demand change and
column3: it will take bravery to embrace a radically different market research business model. Are you willing to move as quickly as your intuition says you can? We hope so. You have business decisions to make.

column1: What can we say? Amazon completely reframed our definition of retail. We love it that they started out focused on books and nailed that before creating a truly global marketplace. Actually
column2: it’s hard to remember life without Amazon. We’re rabidly loyal. And who knows? They may save the US Postal Service while they pursue big ambitions for mobile payments and deliveries via drones. And the idea of turning London’s Underground ticket offices into click-and-collect pickup stations? Brilliant

column1: One man’s trash is another man’s treasure. eBay gave us the ability to auction the shit we no longer find valuable to people who actually do
column2: and they did it by using technology to bring the idea of collaborative consumption to the fore. Nasty Gal’s Sophia Amoruso is just one of scores of entrepreneurs who are grateful for the eBay launchpad. Which reminds us
column3: we’ve got a snow blower that we never use any more

column2: maybe “cool” isn’t always enough to win top place in the market. But taking technology innovation and wrapping it in beautiful design so that it can go viral is brilliant. They have consistently created anticipation (and demand) by rationing new innovations. Apple taught us that simple is beautiful
column3: and we all know that simple isn’t easy.

column2: these guys are well on their way to disrupting the global lodging industry. And the hospitality industry hates them (well
column3: nearly as much as all those government agencies that rely on hospitality taxes). Their stats are nothing short of astounding: 9
column13: another one of our favourite disruptors
column14: is an investor in this most prominent example of the Sharing Economy. They’ve used technology to reduce transaction costs
column15: making sharing easier than ever. And they’re driving scale at a global level that no B&B (or VRBO for that matter) could ever dream of.

column2: what we really love about Kiva is that it takes capital away from the thugs corrupting so many geographies around the world. This microfinance marvel gives each of us the opportunity to change a life with a loan as small as $25. They’ve provided $519 million in loans so far (and counting) with a staggering 99.02% repayment rate. Grab a tissue if you plan to read a case study or two.

column1: Build a better mousetrap and the world will beat a path to your door. And in today’s chaotic new business frontier
column2: better mousetraps are popping up everywhere. In fact
column3: no industry — let alone any company or brand — can afford to stand still.

column1: We’re fascinated by disruptors. Those brave souls who’ve literally replaced industry incumbents
column6: and applied technology to fundamentally change the human experience.

column2: and here are a few of our favourites.

column1: A brilliantly disruptive idea that put Blockbuster out of business – though at one point a strategic decision nearly cost them their entire customer base. But they turned it around and are in a fierce battle against competitors who are much more frightening than Blockbuster ever was: Amazon
column3: and others. Netflix is rare in that they’ve adapted their business model and leveraged new technology to drive customer value. We’ll be watching this space closely.

column1: Forget that “Google it!” is an indispensible call to action. We love any disruptor whose mantra is to be completely transformative or
column3: to go enormous or go home. And the company’s Google[x] experimental wing is exploring space-age technology that could turn healthcare on its head. Everything Google does is about massive disruption (though we’d humbly suggest they stay open to the fact that just because it’s from Google it isn’t necessarily better). But even as we type that
except that Spotify is just the latest in a long string of participants in the very public disruption of the music industry. After all
column4: none of us will ever think about the concept of a personal music collection the same way again. We wonder where this story will end. Just in case
column5: we’re keeping our eye on the new Beats offer.

column1: We can just imagine the dozens – if not hundreds – of telecon executives shedding tears
column3: and gnashing teeth over the stats: 430 million active users globally and more than 50 billion messages each day (which
column5: rivals SMS levels). And these boys from Yahoo remained firm about no advertising and no gimmicks
column6: no matter what the competition did. They were clearly onto something
column7: because Facebook bought them for a stunning $19 billion. As for their growth over the last five years? Mark Zuckerberg put it nicely: “No one in the history of the history of the world has done anything like that.”

column1: What Amazon did for retail Etsy is doing to align business interests with social and environmental responsibility. Actually
column2: scratch that. They’re giving brick and mortar
column4: and mobile retailers a run for their money even as they become one of only 521 Certified B Corporations. No question they’re leveraging technology and disintermediation to change the way independent
column5: creative artists and curators take their goods to market. But they’re also driving incredible scale with more than 1 million active sellers worldwide (hawking over 20 million items)
column7: and $895 million in sales in 2012. Not bad for a company that’s only been profitable since 2009 and in existence since 2005.

column1: Hands down. These guys were the earliest and remain the best
column2: most successful crowdsourcing engine on the planet – and they’ve continued to evolve and increase their level of sophistication since Day 1. As for us? We can barely resist the allure of a Producer credit.

column1: This is a question of how
If you’ve already worked with us or have significant experience on the supplier side of market research
column2: read no further. You already know that market research can be better
column4: and less expensive than it is today. But if you  don’t  believe it’s possible
column5: stay with us for a moment. Keep an open mind. And understand that you’ll need to think outside the boundaries of market research for context – because you won’t find anything like it in the industry.

column3: and cheaper solutions to just about anything now. Certainly more than any of us would have dreamed possible in the 1990s. The products we order from Amazon are exactly the same products found at any retailer
column4: just less expensive and delivered straight to our respective front doors. The songs we download from iTunes are the same ones we’d find in a music store (had we not already stopped going to music stores) but cheaper
column6: and delivered on our terms. And with the likes of VEVO
column10: the music industry will continue its very public digital disruption while teaching a lot of other industries what  not  to do when under fire.

column1: What we’re doing at Mizzouri is not rocket science. In fact
column2: it’s been done in many other service industries as well. For a good look at how the model applies to law firms
column3: click  here .  The model is smart and intuitive
column4: but it hasn’t been leveraged in market research. It’s taken us years of working on the supplier side to fully understand why market research firms cannot and  will  not put these same principles in place. So we’ve done it ourselves
column5: building a better mousetrap from the ground up.

column1: This is how we do it...
We do love efficiency. And disintermediation
column2: which originated in the banking industry in the 1960s
column3: became an efficiency force to be reckoned with by the late 1990s. Very simply
column4: it’s about cutting out the middleman and eliminating non-value add intermediaries in a supply chain. (When was the last time you used a travel agent?) In traditional research
column5: every hand-off across the lifespan of a project is an opportunity for mistakes
column6: and each hand-off adds time and cost. Not only that
column7: every time a research project moves between different supplier entities – or simply from one business unit to another within the same research firm – it gets taxed with an incremental dollop of profit. For example
column8: a large global research firm fielding a quantitative study in three global markets sources respondents from the same sample providers that we use at Mizzouri. But the internal department responsible for finding sample must make a profit
column9: so they mark up the external supplier’s cost. Then each of the countries executing the research marks up those costs again. And the country originating the project marks things up yet again. Clients don’t get better sample in this model
column10: but they certainly pay a lot more for it than they need to. The Mizzouri model doesn’t include middlemen. And with fewer links in the chain
column11: we can reduce the risk of errors

column2: we thoroughly enjoy helping our clients navigate from A to Z. We just don’t believe we need to stop at all 24 letters in between to get there.

column1: Toyota usually gets credit for pioneering this process transformation
column2: but the origins of just in time (JIT) inventory trace as far back as Eli Whitney and Henry Ford. The model focuses on making sure a business has exactly what it needs but only when it needs it – thereby avoiding the carrying costs and increased prices associated with extra inventory. At Mizzouri
column3: we’ve created our internal systems and processes with this in mind. We have a deep global pool of talented researchers
column6: and business professionals. And they’re all enrolled in our variable compensation model
column7: so when they’re not working on projects they’re not part of our cost structure.

column1: This model is a proverbial win-win. It provides our experts with far greater flexibility and financial upside than they’d find in a typical corporate environment. And our clients love the model because it gives them access to top industry talent around the globe (and we mean  really  top talent) without having to pay the “inventory cost” associated with having great brains on our bench.
The same goes for technology. At our disposal are the most advanced and innovative technology solutions available
column2: but we choose not to acquire the companies that have built and run them. We have strong partnership agreements in place
column3: so our clients don’t pay for the overhead associated with holding and maintaining large technology platforms in-house. An additional benefit of this approach is that we’re not forcing these partners to change their own business models to meet our needs
column4: which keeps them focused and affordable.

column1: The idea is simple: deliver precisely the product or service that a customer wants
column2: when he wants it. The model is equally simple: build a standard pre-assembly of core modules and leave the customized bits until the end of the assembly process. (And while you’re at it
column3: use technology to drive down costs while adding warp-speed to supply chain coordination.) Call it mass customization or late stage differentiation. The point is that it speaks to a “customer of one” and takes Built to Order to a new level.

column1: Who’s doing it? Dell and HP
column2: for starters. Who isn’t? The automotive industry as a whole. And not surprisingly
late stage differentiation is built into our process model
column3: and we’ve created structures that are extremely flexible and scaleable. This enables us to design unique and tailored research solutions that have high quality and low cost built in from the very beginning. Our clients don’t pay for more than they actually need. Nor are they forced to buy standard
column4: fixed products that are expensive because they haven’t achieved economies of scale. (In car parlance
column5: imagine the expense incurred when producing a car to meet a demand that never materializes. The same is often true for proprietary
column6: packaged market research products; “inventory” is expensive
column7: and someone ultimately has to pay for it.)

column6: etc. – is part of one giant pipe from the very beginning. Customization is easy
column12: or any other combination of methodologies. At Mizzouri
column13: the opportunities for customization are virtually limitless.

column1: Technologists are brilliant at what they do
column2: and they’re able to deliver breakthrough innovation. They also require specific business models to deliver that innovation.

column1: We don’t try to change them or their business models. Instead
column2: we leverage their technology expertise while providing a bridge to the market research industry. We talk to them in their language
column3: and you can talk to us in yours. We introduce them to a new industry
column4: and we introduce you to breakthrough new ways to answer your business questions. Without question
column5: we don’t chase technology for technology’s sake. We leverage it to solve problems you’ve never been able to solve before – or to solve them with dramatically higher quality and lower cost.

column1: It’s not our strategy to acquire these technology specialists for a variety of reasons
column2: not the least of which is that we want to keep them pure. They do what they love and you gain access to best in class thinking in an incredibly dynamic field. And because we’re not stuck with legacy systems
column3: we can move nimbly to newer
column5: and more efficient systems as they emerge.

column1: We are a full service global research firm offering qualitative
column3: and quantilative research as well as research planning and consulting
column5: and organizational development. We’re also a majority women-owned business.

column1: What makes us different? For perspective
column2: small research agencies and boutiques don’t have the time or capacity to deliver the breadth of capabilities required to meet 90% of a client’s research needs. So
column3: they focus on niche offerings and (in most cases) deliver them very well. But this forces clients to know who can do what – and to work across a wide array of firms in order to meet their needs. And while many of the big guys have amassed the entire spectrum of research capabilities within their networks
column4: those networks aren’t necessarily talking to each other. Moreover
column5: they’re not financially incentivized to be methodologically agnostic
column6: leaving clients to wonder if they’re  really  getting the best of the agency.

column1: We’ve taken a very different approach. We’ve populated our Mizzouri River with top talent across a range of capabilities that we can leverage to meet nearly every client need across virtually every global geography. And this isn’t limited to traditional research. For instance
column2: we deliver mobile surveys in developing countries
column3: global video immersion and transcripted video databasing
column4: 3-D animation and virtual fly-throughs for shopper research and store design
column5: apps for updating and disseminating research findings to geographically dispersed client teams
column6: and more. We have access to sample providers who can cover the majority of the globe. We’re quickly revolutionizing industry approaches to concept testing
column14: and data visualization. We’re continuously improving the research tools and approaches our clients have historically used – and always through the lens of providing better

column1: We’re also passionate about mixed methodologies
column2: and the number of possible combinations within our modular set of tools is virtually infinite. The key? Rapid and fluid customization
column3: not a static suite of inflexible products.

column1: Here are a few examples of problems we’ve recently solved for clients.

column2: our mobile accessories client began to suspect that a new segmentation model was emerging for the category. So

column2: 000 demographically and geographically representative category consumers from a double opt-in panel. We delivered results in 3 days for $4

The study included time-coded heat mapping of the creative executions in order to deliver qualitative understanding as well as statistically significant data. We delivered results in 4 days for $8

column2: more compelling packaging – and wanted to determine which of three design directions they should pursue based on appeal to their existing consumer segments. They also wanted to identify optimization opportunities

column4: and category and packaging heat mapping. We delivered results in 25 days for $70

column1: We designed and executed a blended methodology study in Spanish that included large base online qualitative (quantilative) and quantitative

column3: and confusing aspects of each design (as well as qualitative rationale for the ratings). We delivered results in 3 days for $5

column1: Disruptive thinkers are powerful catalysts. They’re also a helluva lot of fun.
Mizzouri is home to some of the most inspiring people in the industry. Renowned experts who also happen to be extraordinary catalysts for meaningful change. Researchers
column11: designers – all very senior and highly regarded in their fields. And in their free time they’re authors
column17: bloggers
column24: and guerrilla gardeners. There’s a reason you won’t find newly minted MBAs or junior researchers at Mizzouri: it doesn’t fit our business model. Well-trained senior experts are methodologically agnostic and help clients find answers to their business questions more efficiently and cost effectively. They bring tremendous passion and creative problem-solving skills to the party. They enjoy flexing their research intelligence to solve enigmatic business problems. And they love what they do. If you ask us
column25: there’s a lot to be said for that.

She takes a holistic approach to her work and is extremely skilled in integrating data from various sources to find business answers as well as passionately pursue her clients’ business growth – both of which certainly helped her earn Ipsos’ annual  Best Client Service Award .

column1: There are many times when the magic in the data – when the truth of the consumer’s voice – can only be brought to life in video. And for that
column2: clients need a gifted TV and Digital executive producer with expertise in scripting
column5: and leading creative teams. That person is Jay. Born in Windsor UK in the shadow of the Queen’s castle
column6: she resides in London (but longs for the sunshine
column8: and smoothies of Los Angeles). We’re all a bit in awe of her career
column9: over the course of which she’s been a Development Executive for the BBC
column11: and ITV. She’s been a Series Producer for BBC One’s  The Vanessa Show  and SKY1’s  Hotter Sex  (on the heels of SKY1’s  Naked in Westminster ). And just when we thought it couldn’t get more interesting
column12: Jay tells us she’s also been a Celebrity Booker for BBC’s  Comic Relief 5  and has manned the Showbiz Desk for the Daily Mail. Her current clients range from The Prime Minister of the UK to RBS to Ogilvy to Stonewall to Mars. What makes her brilliant? Always having a Plan B for clients with smaller budgets. In her free time she watches movies
column14: and hangs out with horses. By her own admission she’s rubbish at singing and drawing
column15: but she’s a bloody good horse rider
column17: and a very loyal friend. In short

column1: Christian joined Mizzouri after an inspiring 18-year career at Procter & Gamble
column2: where he helped us all stay clean (and blissfully free of dust bunnies) thanks to his work launching Swiffer and his leadership on Tide
column9: and a host of other brands in the US
column11: and Switzerland. He has also lived in Singapore and Sweden
column12: and this global explorer is addicted to podcasts like Stuff You Should Know
column14: and Freakonomics. He’s like that. He treats his brain like a toolbox that he fills with random and seldom used tools that will surely come in handy someday – and as it turns out
column15: he’s gifted at pulling disparate but critical bits of information together for clients. We joke that he’s the Google engine of Mizzouri. Except that he does far more than just serve up answers. He serves up compelling business recommendations.

column1: An entrepreneurial streak seems to run through most of the Mizzouri team
column2: and Kristi is no exception. She started her first company (an on-campus video rental store) when she was in college. Her second venture was a smartphone app technology that analyzed moles for characteristics of melanoma skin cancer – a business that was acquired just a year after launch. But don’t be fooled; Kristi is also a classically trained market researcher who spent six years with Procter & Gamble. While there
column3: she led initiatives all over the world (including work with low income consumers in emerging markets)
column4: and along the way uncovered unique insights about the male shopper that helped drive significant incremental growth for Gillette and Old Spice brands (and earned her a President’s Award). Her current passion? Leveraging her proprietary technology to enable clients to find the information they need in their existing data in  seconds
column6: something that moves as quickly as Kristi does.

column1: There are very few researchers who can say that their consumer insight generation work helped a brand launch from scratch and quickly capture the greatest share in the category. Lena can. Over the course of her 18-year career with Procter & Gamble in Greater China she has led market research initiatives in Laundry
column4: and Fem Care – and now boasts 10+ years of skincare experience in China. She leverages her expert quantitative and qualitative skills to round out her research findings and help clients succeed in this critical business market.

column1: Koga is obsessed with helping global clients lower the risk of their business decisions (and avoid failure) by leveraging critical market and consumer data. He also strongly believes that political and social factors are not to be ignored
column2: and he has deep expertise in public opinion and political polling research in addition to more than 15 years of commercial research experience. Kogo knows his sub-Saharan region well – and even served as the principal statistician in the Biometrics Departments in the Ministry of Agriculture before spending several years with Gallup International. He and his partners lead and conduct our research in 13 sub-Saharan countries
column15: and Madagascar. And while it’s bad enough that Koga leaves us in the dust with his skills in applied mathematics
column16: he leaves us speechless when he starts talking statistics.

column1: Over the course of her six-year career at Procter & Gamble
column2: Lauren didn’t just master brand-building fundamentals
column5: and quantitative methodologies such as market mix modeling
column7: and media effectiveness tracking. She also leveraged her shopper expertise to lead adoption and deployment of a First Moment of Truth tool in North America that has helped P&G deliver with excellence in-store. And she rounded out her extensive work in P&G’s coffee and dish care categories by leading the company’s largest multi-brand effort at the 2012 London Olympics. We expect a driven researcher like Lauren to be an over-achiever in all aspects of her life
column8: and she certainly doesn’t disappoint. This mother
column10: and certified yoga instructor has also trained and certified one of her dogs as a Therapy Dog. But for Lauren
column11: all roads lead back to market research. Her husband is in market research (as are the majority of her friends)
column12: so dinnertime conversations often revolve around anticipated Purchase Intent lift based on optimized POS materials. What a rebel.

column1: After a start at United Biscuits in Trade Marketing
column2: Fred went on to spend much of his 20 plus year career working with (and for) creative agencies including McCann Erickson
column6: and Exposure. After repeatedly stumbling over a persistent knowledge gap in the industry
column7: he began specializing in retail activation based on insight across multiple channels. As a result
column13: and Procter & Gamble rely on Fred’s expertise to deliver retail activation founded on insight and strategy. And we admire his can-do spirit – which isn’t solely exemplified by his backpack trips across far-flung parts of Africa
column16: Fred once found himself locked inside a Spanish toilet right before a big client pitch but deftly launched himself over the transom and made it to the meeting on time. Funny
column17: we’re still so busy laughing that we don’t even remember who won that one.

column1: It’s not often you find a technology expert who fully understands both the agency and the client perspective
column2: but Christian is one of those rare individuals. For the agency
column3: it’s about finding the right operations software
column9: it takes the ability to hear what an organization actually needs even when it’s not overtly stated – and the ability to combine solutions to create what’s right for each situation. That’s where magic happens. And because Christian spent over 25 years with Ipsos in senior global IT roles that were always client facing
column10: he knows how to derive maximum value from technology in a scalable
column11: global way. This highly published New Orleans native revels in the prospect of massive change in the industry
column12: and will giddily tell you that decades of survey-based methods are being disrupted by tech and the Internet of Things. But then he’ll also tell you that his jambalaya is second to none – and we can vouch for that.

column1: Though arguably still early in her career
column2: Hilari has garnered impressive experience through her role at Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia in New York (where she developed competitive retail analysis and planned
column4: and styled events at the MSLO offices) as well as her work with clients such as The Home Depot
column9: and Hershey. A graduate of Vanderbilt University with a B.S. in Organizational Development and a Masters in Leadership & Organizational Performance
column10: Hilari is also a nationally recognized lifestyle blogger. (She’s also a dangerous and prolific baker
column11: to which our ever-expanding waistlines can attest.) She is a master of organization – something that serves her clients well when she’s the one breaking their complex projects into manageable pieces with clear structure. What you might never learn outside a game of Truth or Dare is that Hilari was a professional figure skater for 15 years. And we’re convinced that 15 years of 4AM practices accounts for the fact that she’s always the first one in the office.

column1: Barrett’s career follows a clear and consistent theme of client service. She has held Account Executive roles for The Voice-Tribune
column3: and Dot Fox – all the while leading funding development
column5: and ticket sales for numerous non-profit entities. This highly driven Louisville native is a proud Derby
column7: and bluegrass lover who’s happy to remind us that Jennifer Lawrence
column9: and My Morning Jacket all hail from her hometown. A few years ago
column10: Barrett secured a rare (and highly coveted) spot in NYC’s New School for Drama  Summer Immersion Experience
column11: which is just one in a long list of adventures that includes navigating the treacherous Wild River Range in Wyoming before summiting the Grand Teton. When she’s not helping to lead our efforts in video databasing
column12: you’ll find Barrett practicing Ashtanga yoga
column13: philosophizing with friends over Lagunitas IPA
column14: and belting out Brandi Carlile. (And usually in that order.)

column1: Gonzalo moved from Miami to Nashville to join Mizzouri – and this native of Spain is still debating whether or not he should buy cowboy boots. We’ll convince him… The most global of our Nashville team
column11: and the US. He speaks Spanish
column14: and Mandarin. And as if  that  weren’t enough to intimidate us
column15: his experience as a consultant and analyst in Shanghai has given him a tremendous understanding of the social media
column17: and marketing strategies that are invaluable for companies interested in expanding to China. (How did he end up there

column19: bought a one-way ticket to Shanghai
column20: and kept his fingers crossed.) Gonzalo holds a B.A. in Political Science from Davidson College and a Masters in Advanced European & International Studies from the Centre Internationale de Formation Européenne. And when he’s not eating BBQ or complaining about the Dolphins
column21: you’ll find him eating BBQ and complaining about the Dolphins.

column1: Cognitive Neuroscience Research Associate           Nashville USA
Ask Liz what she’s passionate about and she’ll quickly answer
column2: “Applying neuroscience in order to understand cognition and deliver better research.” She’s not kidding. This Certified Advanced Brain Trainer holds a Masters degree with merit in Cognitive Neuroscience from the University of Essex in Colchester
column3: England. She has established EEG correlates involved in unconscious brand priming and its effect on conscious motivation
column7: and analyzed data. She has refined experimental procedures – and along the way she has gained significant understanding of the theoretical underpinnings of research through her own study of research on prospective and associative memory
column8: the neural correlates of emotion processing
column12: and cued recall. She’s even trained to independently operate the electroencephalogram (EEG) and interpret the data. All of which makes our heads hurt. But we do take comfort in the fact that she’ll give Kim Dedeker a run for her money on that “friendly” game of HORSE
column13: since Liz played D1 basketball in college.

Q. How is InfoWorks different from other places you have worked?
A.  InfoWorks not only cares about its employees but also the employee’s family. InfoWorks takes thoughtful measures to let people within the organization know that they care.
A.  The people. I’m lucky enough to work with both clients and colleagues who I would consider friends.
Q. What is the best part about your job?

A.  The best part about my job is the variety of my experiences which are always changing. Working for a consulting firm lets me work with a variety of industries and people. Each project is always different. There are so many diverse industries in the Nashville area. Working with each of them
column3: and learning my way around them is a fun and sometimes challenging experience.

column2: or around Nashville by finding companies that might be in need of InfoWorks’ assistance.

column5: software documentation and clinical workflows. It was a fun project!

column1: Construction Employment Is Climbing Across The Nation
Across the nation construction employment set a five year high in November adding 20
column3: the construction unemployment rate fell to 7.5% representing the lowest unemployment rate for the month in seven years. According to Ken Simonson
column4: the AGC of America's Chief Economist
column5: November was a good month overall for construction workers and businesses. November continues a slow and steady recovery from the recession.

column1: According to the latest available statistics construction employment expanded in 228 metro areas
column2: declined in 64 areas and was unchanged in 47 market areas between October 2013 and October 2014. AGC of America Association officials noted that newly released federal figures show construction spending increased by 3.3% between October 2013 and October 2014 as demand slowly expanded. As construction activity increases the challenge for firms is rapidly becoming the acquisition of qualified employees to perform the work needed to move construction projects forward. In fact
column3: 83 percent of firms reported trouble finding qualified workers which is impacting competition and driving many firms to change the way they operate.

column2: from October 2013 to October 2014 construction employment grew by 6% adding an additional 7
column3: 000 jobs. The rate of growth varied by market area with the Cleveland
column4: Tennessee area growing by 19% and Nashville - Davidson - Murfreesboro-Franklin growing by 11%. To learn more about construction employment trends across the nation and in Tennessee

The AGC of Tennessee Chronicle  - A New E-Newsletter For Members

The AGC of Tennessee has developed a new publication for members. The e-newsletter is published to provide you with regular updates on AGC of Tennessee news and other information to members. The e-newsletter will be in addition to periodic legislative updates and other new you receive from the AGC of Tennessee office Nashville thoughout the year. We invite suggestions for topics that are newsworthy for members of the association. We hope you find the AGC of Tennessee Chronicle informative and enjoyable to read!
